    5# **Config** - *encapsulates certain [`nconf`](https://github.com/flatiron/nconf)
    6# behaviors for a consistent way to load configuration data from files
    7# or the environment.*
    8#
    9# EXAMPLE OF USE
    10#
    11# var config = require('inote-util').config.init();
    12# var prop = config.get('my:property');
    13#
    14# `Config` will load the configuration from several sources.
    15#
    16# In order of precedence:
    17#
    18# 1. "Override" values passed to the `init` function.
    19#
    20# 2. Command line parameters (`--name value`).
    21#
    22# 3. A JSON-format configuration file (from a location deterimined by
    23# `NODE_ENV`, `config_dir` or `config_file`).
    24#
    25# 4. Environment variables.
    26#
    27# 5. A "default" JSON-format configuration file at `${config_dir}/config.json`.
    28#
    29# 6. "Default" values passed to the `init` function.
    30#
    31# To discover a configuration file (as used in step 3 above), `Config` will:
    32#
    33# a. Look for `NODE_ENV`, `config_dir` or `config_file` environment variables.
    34#
    35# b. If `config_dir` is set, the value will be used as the "parent" directory
    36# of the configuration files. (If `config_dir` is not set, it defaults to
    37# the directory `config` within the working directory from which the current
    38# Node.js process was launched.)
    39#
    40# c. If `NODE_ENV` is set and a file named `${NODE_ENV}.json` exists within
    41# the `config_dir`, that file will be used.
    42#
    43# d. If `config_file` is set, that file will be used.
    44#
    45
    468class Config
    47
    488 constructor:(defaults=null,overrides=null)->
    498 @init(defaults,overrides) if defaults? or overrides?
    50
    51 _load_if_exists:(file)=>
    5218 if file? and fs.existsSync(file)
    5310 @nconf.file(file)
    5410 return true
    55 else
    568 return false
    57
    58 init:(defaults=null,overrides=null)->
    598 @nconf = require 'nconf'
    608 @nconf.overrides(overrides) if overrides? # First, use any overrides that are provided.
    618 @nconf.argv() # Next, command line parameters.
    628 @nconf.env ['NODE_ENV','config_file','config_dir'] # Then, fetch certain values from the environment variables (but nothing else yet), if they aren't already set.
    638 config_dir = @nconf.get('config_dir') # Now, if there is a `config_dir` directory specified, use that instead of the default `CONFIG_DIR`.
    648 if config_dir?
    652 if fs.existsSync(config_dir)
    662 CONFIG_DIR = config_dir
    67 else
    680 console.error "Custom config_dir #{config_dir} not found; aborting."
    690 process.exit(1)
    70 else
    716 config_dir = CONFIG_DIR
    728 if @nconf.get('NODE_ENV')? # If there is a `[CONFIG_DIR]/[NODE_ENV].json` file, try to load that.
    738 @_load_if_exists(path.join(config_dir,"#{@nconf.get('NODE_ENV')}.json"))
    748 config_file = @nconf.get('config_file') #If there is a `config_file` variable, try to load that.
    758 if config_file?
    762 unless @_load_if_exists(config_file)
    770 console.error "Custom config_file #{config_file} not found; aborting."
    780 process.exit(1)
    798 @nconf.env() # Pull remaining values from the environment variables
    808 @_load_if_exists(path.join(config_dir,'config.json')) # Finally if there is a `[CONFIG_DIR]/config.json` configuration file, use that.
    818 @nconf.defaults(defaults) if defaults? # ...and use any provided defaults.
    828 return @nconf
    83
    848exports.config = new Config()
    85

    1# This `index.coffee` (or the generated `index.js`) file is the base file that
    2# in loaded when a user `require`s `inote-util`.

    4# <i style="color:#666;font-size:80%">(Note: If you are viewing the [docco](http://jashkenas.github.io/docco/)-generated HTML version of this file, use the "Jump To..." menu in the upper right corner to navigate to the annotated versions of other source files.)</i>

    6# ## Calculate LIB_DIR
    7
    8# As we do throughout the source files in this module, in order to
    9# support test coverage analysis, we deterine whether we should load
    10# additional local files from the default `lib` directory or from the
    11# `lib-cov` directory that contains an instrumented version of
    12# the source code (when present).
    13
    141fs = require 'fs'
    151path = require 'path'
    161HOMEDIR = path.join __dirname, '..'
    171LIB_COV = path.join HOMEDIR, 'lib-cov'
    181LIB = path.join HOMEDIR, 'lib'
    191LIB_DIR = if fs.existsSync(LIB_COV) then LIB_COV else LIB
    20
    21# ## Export Objects to the External Namespace
    22
    23# `sources` enumerates the files from which we'll load objects to export.
    24
    251sources = [
    26 'util'
    27 'stopwatch'
    28 'config'
    29]
    30
    31# Now we simply load (`require`) the requisite files and pass along whatever
    32# they've exported to the module's `exports` object.
    33
    341for file in sources
    353 exported = require path.join(LIB_DIR,file)
    363 for k,v of exported
    374 exports[k] = v

    1# <i style="color:#666;font-size:80%">(Note: If you are viewing the [docco](http://jashkenas.github.io/docco/)-generated HTML version of this file, use the "Jump To..." menu in the upper right corner to navigate to the annotated versions of other source files.)</i>
    2
    3# `Stopwatch` is a simple utility that can be used to track and
    4# report the time it takes to do some thing in your JavaScript
    5# code.
    6#
    7# ## Importing
    8#
    9# SW = require('stopwatch').Stopwatch
    10#
    11# ## Basic Use
    12#
    13# timer = SW.start();
    14# // ...do something...
    15# timer.stop();
    16# console.log("Start Time: ",timer.start_time);
    17# console.log("Finish Time: ",timer.finish_time);
    18# console.log("Elapsed Time:",timer.elapsed_time);
    19#
    20# ## Wrapped (Synchronous)
    21#
    22# timer = SW.time( some_method );
    23# console.log("some_method took",timer.elapsed_time,"millis to complete.");
    24#
    25# ## "Cookies"
    26#
    27# The `start` and `time` methods accept an optional map of attributes
    28# that will be bundled with the returned timer. For example:
    29#
    30# timer = SW.start({label:"foo"});
    31# // ...do something...
    32# timer.stop();
    33# console.log(timer.label," Start Time: ",timer.start_time);
    34# console.log(timer.label,"Finish Time: ",timer.finish_time);
    35# console.log(timer.label,"Elapsed Time:",timer.elapsed_time);
    36#
    37
    38# ## The Implementation
    39
    40# **Stopwatch** - *a simple timer.*
    41
    421class Stopwatch
    43
    44 # ## Methods
    45
    46 # **start** - *start a new timer*
    47 #
    48 # Returns a running timer.
    49 #
    50 # The returned object will have a `stop()` method
    51 # by which to stop the timer and a `start_time` attribute
    52 # indicating the date and time at which the timer was started.
    53 #
    54 # Once stopped, the attributes `finish_time` and `elapsed_time`
    55 # will be available in the timer.
    56 #
    57 # Any properties of the optional `base` object will also be
    58 # availble in the returned timer.
    59
    60 # The `start` method generates a new timer object.
    611 start:(base={})->
    62
    637 timer = {}
    64
    65 # If any `base` object was provided, copy its properties into the timer.
    667 if base?
    677 for n,v of base
    682 timer[n] = v
    69
    70 # `timer.start_time` contains the initial start time.
    717 timer.start_time = new Date()
    72
    73 # `timer.stop()` stops the timer; it can only be stopped once.
    74 # Once stopped, the `finish_time` and `elapsed_time` value are calculated.
    757 timer.stop = ()->
    76 # If any lap times have been taken, add one final lap
    77 # (and make sure to reuse the *exact* same finish time as the final lap).
    787 if timer.laps?
    791 timer.lap()
    801 timer.finish_time = timer.laps[timer.laps.length-1].lap_finish_time
    81 # Otherwise use the current time.
    82 else
    836 timer.finish_time = new Date()
    84
    85 # Elapsed time is simply the duration from start to finish.
    867 timer.elapsed_time = timer.finish_time - timer.start_time
    87
    88 # Remove the `stop` and `lap` methods, this timer is done.
    897 delete timer.stop
    907 delete timer.lap
    91
    927 return timer
    93
    94 # `timer.lap()` records a lap-time in a (newly created) `timer.laps` array.
    95 # Each lap descriptor inclues `lap_start_time`, `lap_finish_time`,
    96 # `lap_time` and `lap_elapsed_time` (where `lap_time` is the duration of the
    97 # lap itself and `lap_elapsed_time` is the duration from the start of the
    98 # overall timer to the end of the lap).
    997 timer.lap = ()->
    1004 lap_finish = new Date()
    1014 if timer.laps?
    1023 lap_start = timer.laps[timer.laps.length-1].lap_finish_time
    103 else
    1041 lap_start = timer.start_time
    1054 timer.laps ?= []
    1064 timer.laps.push {
    107 lap_start_time: lap_start
    108 lap_finish_time: lap_finish
    109 lap_time: lap_finish - lap_start
    110 lap_elapsed_time: lap_finish - timer.start_time
    111 }
    1124 return timer
    1137 return timer
    114
    115 # **time** - *time a synchronous method*
    116 #
    117 # Runs the specified function, returning a stopped
    118 # timer indicating how long the function took to execute.
    119 #
    120 # Any properties of the optional `base` object will also be
    121 # availble in the returned timer.
    122 time:(base,fn)->
    1232 if typeof base is 'function'
    1241 fn = base
    1251 base = fn
    1262 timer = @start(base)
    1272 fn()
    1282 return timer.stop()
    129
    130# ## Exports
    131
    132# `Stopwatch` is exported as a singleton object.
    1331exports.Stopwatch = new Stopwatch()
    134

    5# **Util** - *collects assorted utility functions*
    61class Util
    7
    8 # ## String Manipulation and Formatting
    9
    10 # **trim** - *removes leading and trailing whitespace from a (possibly `null`) string.*
    111 @trim:(str)=>str?.replace /(^\s+)|(\s+$)/ig, ""
    12
    13 # **isnt_blank** - *returns `true` iff the given string is not `null` and contains at least one non-whitespace character.*
    1433 @isnt_blank:(str)=>(str? and /[^\s]/.test(str))
    15
    16 # **is_blank** - *returns `true` iff the given string is `null`, empty or only contains whitespace characters.*
    1723 @is_blank:(str)=>not(@isnt_blank(str))
    18
    19 # **blank_to_null** - converts blank strings or attribute values to `null`.
    20 @blank_to_null:(data)=>
    2111 if typeof data is 'string'
    229 if Util.is_blank(data)
    233 return null
    24 else
    252 for k,v of data
    264 if Util.is_blank(v)
    273 delete data[k]
    283 data[k] = undefined
    298 return data
    30
    31 # **truncate** - *a minimally "smart" truncation that attempts to truncate a string at a word boundarie*
    32 #
    33 # Truncates `text` to at most `width` characters, appending the specified
    34 # `marker` when an actual truncation occurred. (Pass an empty string--`''`--to
    35 # prevent a marker from being added to the truncated string.)
    36 #
    37 # The returned string will be *at most* `width` characters wide (including the
    38 # `marker`), but it may be less if the method can find a more suitable breaking
    39 # point near the end of the string. (Specifically, the algorithm tries to avoid
    40 # truncating a string in the middle of a "word".)
    41 @truncate:(text,width,marker='…')=>
    4268 if not text? or not text.length? or text.length <= width
    4324 return text
    44 else
    4544 marker ?= ''
    4644 max_shorten = 10 # maximum number of characters to step back while looking for a word boundary
    4744 break_chars = /\.|\!|\?|\,|\:|\-|\s|\0|\)|\(|\[|\]|\{|\}|\\|\/|\\|\<|\>|\"|\'/ # characters recognized as word boundaries
    4844 short_width = max_width = width-(marker.length)
    4944 while short_width > (width-max_shorten)
    50252 if break_chars.test(text.charAt(short_width))
    5124 return "#{text.substring(0,short_width)}#{marker}"
    52 else
    53228 short_width--
    5420 return "#{text.substring(0,max_width)}#{marker}"
    55
    56 # **escape_for_json** - *escapes a string for use as literal characters in a JSON string.*
    57 #
    58 # Escapes the given string so that it can be inserted
    59 # into a JSON string. For example, given:
    60 #
    61 # He said, "I know."
    62 #
    63 # `escape_for_json` returns:
    64 #
    65 # He said, \"I know.\"
    66 #
    67 # Note that the returned string is *not* wrapped in quotation marks.
    68 @escape_for_json:(str)=>
    699 if str?
    708 str = JSON.stringify(str)
    718 str = str.substring(1,str.length-1)
    728 return str
    73 else
    741 return null
    75
    76 # **escape_for_regexp** - *escapes a string for use as literal characters in regular expression.*
    774 @escape_for_regexp:(str)=>str?.replace(/([.?*+^$[\]\/\\(){}|-])/g, "\\$1")
    78
    79
    80 # Returns true if the given string is `t`, `true`, `y`, `yes`, `on`, `1`, etc.
    8123 @truthy_string:(s)=>/^((T(rue)?)|(Y(es)?)|(ON)|1)$/i.test("#{s}")
    82
    83 # Returns true if the given string is `f`, `false`, `no`, `off`, `0`, etc.
    8426 @falsey_string:(s)=>/^((F(alse)?)|(No?)|(OFF)|0)$/i.test("#{s}")
    85
    86 # ## Padding (of Strings and Arrays)
    87
    88 # **lpad** - *left-pad a string or array.*
    89 #
    90 # When `value` is an array, this method invokes `lpad_array`.
    91 # When `value` is a string, this method invokes `lpad_string`.
    92 @lpad:(value,width,pad)=>
    9324 unless value?
    941 throw new Error("value must not be null")
    95 else
    9623 if Array.isArray(value)
    9712 return @lpad_array(value,width,pad)
    98 else
    9911 return @lpad_string(value,width,pad)
    100
    101 # **lpad_array** - *left-pad an array.*
    102 #
    103 # Returns an array of at least `width` elements generated
    104 # by prepending the specified `pad_elt` to (a copy of) the
    105 # given `value`.
    106 @lpad_array:(value=[],width=8,pad_elt=null)=>
    10712 while value.length < width
    10817 value = [pad_elt].concat value
    10912 return value
    110
    111 # **lpad_string** - *left-pad a string.*
    112 #
    113 # Returns a string of at least `width` characters generated
    114 # by prepending the specified `pad_char` to (a copy of) the
    115 # given `value`.
    116 #
    117 # `pad_char` *should* be exactly one character wide.
    118 @lpad_string:(value="",width=8,pad_char=" ")=>
    11911 if "#{pad_char}".length is 0
    1201 throw new Error("pad must not be empty")
    12110 value = "#{value}"
    12210 while value.length < width
    12312 value = pad_char + value
    12410 return value
    125
    126 # **rpad** - *right-pad a string or array.*
    127 #
    128 # When `value` is an array, this method invokes `rpad_array`.
    129 # When `value` is a string, this method invokes `rpad_string`.
    130 @rpad:(value,width,pad)=>
    13117 unless value?
    1321 throw new Error("value must not be null")
    133 else
    13416 if Array.isArray(value)
    1355 return @rpad_array(value,width,pad)
    136 else
    13711 return @rpad_string(value,width,pad)
    138
    139 # **rpad_array** - *right-pad an array.*
    140 #
    141 # Returns an array of at least `width` elements generated
    142 # by appending the specified `pad_elt` to (a copy of) the
    143 # given `value`.
    144 @rpad_array:(value=[],width=8,pad_elt=null)=>
    1455 while value.length < width
    1466 value.push pad_elt
    1475 return value
    148
    149 # **rpad_string** - *right-pad a string.*
    150 #
    151 # Returns a string of at least `width` characters generated
    152 # by appending the specified `pad_char` to (a copy of) the
    153 # given `value`.
    154 #
    155 # `pad_char` *should* be exactly one character wide.
    156 @rpad_string:(value="",width=8,pad_char=" ")=>
    15711 if "#{pad_char}".length is 0
    1581 throw new Error("pad must not be empty")
    159 else
    16010 value = "#{value}"
    16110 while value.length < width
    16212 value += pad_char
    16310 return value
    164
    165 # ## Numbers
    166
    167 # **round_decimal** - *round a number to the specified precision*
    168 #
    169 # Formats the given `value` as a decimal string with `digits` signficant
    170 # digits to the right of the decimal point.
    171 #
    172 # For example, given `v = 1234.567` then:
    173 #
    174 # - `round_decimal(v,0)` yields `"1235"`
    175 # - `round_decimal(v,1)` yields `"1234.6"`
    176 # - `round_decimal(v,2)` yields `"1234.57"`
    177 # - `round_decimal(v,3)` yields `"1234.567"`
    178 # - `round_decimal(v,4)` yields `"1234.5670"`
    179 # - `round_decimal(v,5)` yields `"1234.56700"`
    180 # - `round_decimal(v,-1)` yields `"1230"`
    181 # - `round_decimal(v,-2)` yields `"1200"`
    182 # - `round_decimal(v,-3)` yields `"1000"`
    183 # - `round_decimal(v,-4)` yields `"0"`
    184 #
    185 # Returns `null` if `value` is not a number and cannot
    186 # be coerced into one. (Note that this method uses a less
    187 # permissive form of coercion that `parseInt` and `parseFloat`.
    188 # The input value must be a decimal string in standard (non-scientific)
    189 # notation.)
    190 @round_decimal:(value,digits=0)=>
    19154 unless value?
    1921 return null
    193 else
    19453 unless typeof value is 'number'
    19537 if /^\s*-?(([0-9]+(\.[0-9]+))|(\.[0-9]+))\s*$/.test "#{value}"
    19630 value = parseFloat(value)
    197 else
    1987 return null
    19946 if isNaN(value)
    2001 return null
    20145 else if digits >= 0
    20236 return value.toFixed(digits)
    203 else
    2049 factor = Math.pow(10,Math.abs(digits))
    2059 return "#{(Math.round(value/factor))*factor}"
    206
    207 # **is_int** - *check if the given object is an (optionally signed) simple integer value*
    208 #
    209 # Returns `true` if the given value is (or can be converted to) a
    210 # valid integer (without any rounding). E.g., `is_int(3)` and `is_int("3")`
    211 # yield `true` but `is_int(3.14159)` and `is_int("3.0")` yield `false`.
    212 @is_int:(v)=>
    21312 unless v?
    2141 return false
    215 else
    21611 return /^-?[1-9][0-9]*$/.test "#{v}"
    217
    218 # ## Objects and Arrays
    219
    220 # **trim_trailing_null** - *remove trailing `null` values from an array*
    221 #
    222 # Removes any trailing `null` values from the given array.
    223 # Leading or interspersed `null` values are left alone.
    224 # E.g., given `[null,'foo',null,'bar',null,null]` returns `[null,'foo',null,'bar']`.
    225 @trim_trailing_null: (a)=>
    22612 a = [].concat(a)
    22712 b = []
    22812 while a.length > 0
    22945 v = a.pop()
    23045 if v?
    23124 b.unshift v
    23221 else if b.length > 0
    2337 b.unshift v
    23412 return b
    235
    236
    237 # **right_shift_args** - *convert trailing `null` values to leading `null` values*
    238 #
    239 # Given a list of arguments that might contain trailing `null` values, returns an array
    240 # of the same length, but with leading rather than trailing `null`s.
    241 # E.g,.:
    242 #
    243 # right_shift_args('a',null)
    244 #
    245 # returns:
    246 #
    247 # [ null, 'a' ]
    248 #
    249 # and,
    250 #
    251 # right_shift_args(1,null,2,null,null)
    252 #
    253 # returns:
    254 #
    255 # [ null, null, 1, null, 2 ]
    256 #
    257 # This method can be used to allow the leading arguments to a function to
    258 # be the optional ones. For example, consider the function signature:
    259 #
    260 # function foo(a,b,callback)
    261 #
    262 # Using `right_shift_args` we can make `a` and `b` the optional arguments such that
    263 # `foo(callback)` is equivalent to `foo(null,null,callback)` and `foo('x',callback)`
    264 # is equivalent to `foo(null,'x',callback)`.
    265 #
    266 # In CoffeeScript, this can be achieved with the following idiom:
    267 #
    268 # foo:(a,b,c)->
    269 # [a,b,c] = Util.right_shift_args(a,b,c)
    270 #
    271 # In JavaScript, you'll need to unwind the returned array on your own:
    272 #
    273 # function foo(a,b,c,d) {
    274 # var args = Util.right_shift_args(a,b,c,d);
    275 # a = args[0]; b = args[1]; c = args[2]; d = args[3];
    276 # }
    277 #
    2784 @right_shift_args: (values...)=>@lpad(Util.trim_trailing_null(values),values.length,null)
    279
    280 # **paginate_list** - *extract a sub-array based on offset and limit*
    281 #
    282 # Given a list (array), returns the sublist defined by `offset` and `limit`.
    28312 @paginate_list:(list,offset=0,limit=20)=>list[offset...(offset+limit)]
    284
    285 # **remove_falsey** - *`delete` any attribute whose value evaluates to false*
    286 # Returns a new map or array, with "falsey" values removed.
    287 @remove_falsey:(map)=>
    28834 unless map?
    2891 return map
    29033 else if Array.isArray(map)
    29116 new_array = []
    29216 for elt in map
    29352 if elt
    29421 new_array.push elt
    29516 return new_array
    29617 else if typeof map is 'object'
    29710 new_map = {}
    29810 for n,v of map
    29933 if v
    30013 new_map[n] = v
    30110 return new_map
    3027 else unless map
    3033 return null
    304 else
    3054 return map
    306
    307 # **merge** - *merge multiple maps into a new, combined map*
    308 #
    309 # Given two (or more) maps, `a` and `b`, creates a new map containing the
    310 # elements of each. If `a` and `b` share a key, the value in `b` will
    311 # overwrite the value in `a`.
    312 @merge:(args...)=>
    3136 map = {}
    3146 if args.length is 1 and Array.isArray(args[0])
    3152 args = args[0]
    3166 for m in args
    31720 for n,v of m
    31852 map[n] = v
    3196 return map

    321 # **shallow_clone** - *create a "shallow" copy of an object*

    324 # Any object-valued entry in `map` will *not* be cloned.
    325 # The new map will contain a reference to the same underlying object
    326 # as the original map.
    327 #
    328 # If `map` is `null`, the value `null` is returned.
    329 @shallow_clone:(map)=>
    3302 if map?
    3311 new_map = {}
    3321 for k,v of map
    3335 new_map[k] = v
    3341 return new_map
    335 else
    3361 return null

    338 # **subset_of** - *check whether on array contains another arrays as if they are sets *
    339 #
    340 # Given two arrays `a` and `b`, returns `true` if every element of
    341 # `a` is also found in `b`.
    342 #
    343 # Note that the arrays are treated as true *sets*. The number of times
    344 # a given entry appears in each array is ignored--only the presence or
    345 # absence of a value is significant. (For example, `[1,1]` is considered
    346 # a subset of `[1]`.)
    347 @subset_of:(a,b)=>
    34840 unless a? and Array.isArray(a) and b? and Array.isArray(b)
    3492 throw new Error("Expected arrays.")
    350 else
    35138 for e in a
    35278 unless e in b
    35314 return false
    35424 return true

    359 # **strict_subset_of** - *check whether on array strictly contains another arrays as if they are sets *

    362 # `a` is also found in `b` *and* at least one element of `b` does not
    363 # appear in `a`.
    364 #
    365 # Note that the arrays are treated as true *sets*. The number of times
    366 # a given entry appears in each array is ignored--only the presence or
    367 # absence of a value is significant. (For example, `[1,1]` is considered
    368 # a subset of `[1]`.)
    36915 @strict_subset_of:(a,b)=>@subset_of(a,b) and not @subset_of(b,a) # Note: there are probably more efficient ways to do this.
    370

    3727 @is_strict_subset_of:(args...)=>@strict_subset_of(args...)

    374 # **sets_are_equal** - *compare two arrays as if they were sets*
    375 #
    376 # Given two arrays `a` and `b`, returns `true` if every element of
    377 # `a` is also found in `b` and every element of `b` is also found in `a`.
    378 #
    379 # Note that the arrays are treated as true *sets*. Both the order of
    380 # and number of times a given entry appears in each array is ignored--only
    381 # the presence or absence of a value is significant. (For example, `[1,2]` has
    382 # set equality with `[2,1]` and `[1,2,1]` has set equality with `[2,2,1]`.)
    383 @sets_are_equal:(a,b)=>
    38410 unless a? and Array.isArray(a) and b? and Array.isArray(b)
    3851 throw new Error("Expected arrays.")
    386 else
    3879 for e in a
    38821 unless e in b
    3892 return false
    3907 for e in b
    39120 unless e in a
    3922 return false
    3935 return true
    394
    395 # Returns `true` iff the given arrays contain equal (`===`) elements in the
    396 # exact same order. (Also see `sets_are_equal`).
    397 @arrays_are_equal:(a,b)=>
    39826 unless a? and Array.isArray(a) and b? and Array.isArray(b)
    3991 throw new Error("Expected arrays.")
    400 else
    40125 unless a.length is b.length
    4021 return false
    403 else
    40424 for elt,i in a
    40543 unless elt is b[i]
    4062 return false
    40722 return true
    408
    409 # Returns a clone of `array` with duplicate values removed
    410 # When `key` is specified, elements of the array are treated as maps, and the
    411 # specified key field is used to test for equality
    412 @uniquify:(array,key)=>
    41328 clone = []
    41428 if key?
    41520 keys = []
    41620 for elt in array
    41744 unless elt[key] in keys
    41830 clone.push elt
    41930 keys.push elt[key]
    420 else
    4218 for elt in array
    42238 console.log elt
    42338 unless elt in clone
    42417 clone.push elt
    42517 console.log "pushed"
    42628 return clone
    427
    428 # Given a list of objects, creates a map from `elt[key_field]` to `elt`.
    429 #
    430 # The `options` map may contain:
    431 #
    432 # * `transform` - a function used to transform the value of
    433 # `elt[key_field]` before using it as the map key.
    434 #
    435 # * `duplicates` - a string indicating how to handle duplicate keys:
    436 # * `duplicates="overwrite"` - replace the old value with the new value (the default)
    437 # * `duplicates="stack"` - create an array containing both values (in sequecne)
    438 # * `duplicates="merge"` - merge the objects using `Util.merge(old,new)`
    439 # * `duplicates="skip"` - keep the old value and ignore the new one
    440 @object_array_to_map:(array,key_field,options={})=>
    4416 xform = options?.transform ? ((x)->x)
    4426 duplicates = options?.duplicates ? "overwrite"
    4436 unless duplicates in ["overwrite","stack","merge","skip"]
    4441 throw new Error("Unrecognized value for duplicates option. Found \"#{duplicates}\". Expected \"overwrite\", \"stack\", \"skip\", \"merge\" or null.")
    4455 map = {}
    4465 for elt in array
    44716 key = xform(elt[key_field])
    44816 if map[key]? and duplicates isnt "overwrite"
    4495 if duplicates is 'stack'
    4503 if Array.isArray(map[key])
    4511 map[key].push elt
    452 else
    4532 map[key] = [map[key],elt]
    4542 else if duplicates is 'merge'
    4551 map[key] = @merge(map[key],elt)
    456 # else if duplicates is 'skip'
    457 # # do nothing
    458 else
    45911 map[key] = elt
    4605 return map

    464 # **hex_to_rgb_triplet** - *convert a hex-based `#rrggbb` string to decimal `[r,g,b]` values*
    465 #
    466 # Given an HTML/CSS-style hex color string, yields an array of the R,G and B values.
    467 # E.g. `hex_to_rgb("#3300FF")` yields `[51,0,255]`.
    468 # The leading `#` character is optional, and both uppercase and lowercase letters
    469 # are supported.
    470 @hex_to_rgb_triplet:(hex)=>
    47120 result = /^\s*#?([a-f\d]{2})([a-f\d]{2})([a-f\d]{2})\s*$/i.exec(hex);
    47220 if result?
    47318 return [
    474 parseInt(result[1],16)
    475 parseInt(result[2],16)
    476 parseInt(result[3],16)
    477 ]
    478 else
    4792 return null
    480
    481 # **hex_to_rgb_strng** - *convert a hex-based `#rrggbb` string to a decimal-based `rgb(r,g,b)` string*
    482 #
    483 # Given an HTML/CSS-style hex color string, yields the corresponding `rgb(R,G,B)`
    484 # form. E.g. `hex_to_rgb("#3300FF")` yields `rgb(51,0,255)`.
    485 # The leading `#` character is optional, and both uppercase and lowercase letters
    486 # are supported.
    487 @hex_to_rgb_string:(hex)=>
    48819 [r,g,b] = @hex_to_rgb_triplet(hex) ? [null,null,null]
    48919 if r? and g? and b?
    49018 return "rgb(#{r},#{g},#{b})"
    491 else
    4921 return null
    493
    494
    495 # **rgb_string_to_triplet** - *extract the `[r,g,b]` values from an `rgb(r,g,b)` string*
    496 @rgb_string_to_triplet:(rgb)=>
    49718 result = /^\s*rgb\s*\(\s*([0-9]+)\s*,\s*([0-9]+)\s*,\s*([0-9]+)\s*\)\s*$/i.exec(rgb)
    49818 if result?
    49917 r = parseInt(result[1])
    50017 g = parseInt(result[2])
    50117 b = parseInt(result[3])
    50217 return [r,g,b]
    503 else
    5041 return null

    506 # **rgb_to_hex** - *convert `r`, `g` and `b` components or an `rgb(r,g,b`) string to a hex-based `#rrggbb` string*
    507 #
    508 # Given an RGB triplet returns the equivalent HTML/CSS-style hex string.
    509 # E.g, `rgb_to_hex(51,0,255)` yields `#3300FF`.
    510 @rgb_to_hex:(r,g,b)=>
    51118 if typeof r is 'string' and not g? and not b?
    51217 [r,g,b] = @rgb_string_to_triplet(r) ? [null,null,null]
    51318 unless r? and g? and b?
    5141 return null
    515 else
    51617 i2h = (i)->
    51751 h = i.toString(16)
    51851 return if h.length is 1 then "0#{h}" else h
    51917 return "##{i2h(r)}#{i2h(g)}#{i2h(b)}"

    521 # ## Random Bytes and Strings

    523 # **random_bytes** - *generate a string of random bytes*
    524 #
    525 # Generates a string of `count` pseudo-random bytes in the specified encoding.
    526 # (Defaults to `hex`.)
    527 #
    528 # Note that `count` specifies the number of *bytes* to be generated. The encoded
    529 # string may be more or less than `count` *characters*.
    530 @random_bytes:(count=32,enc='hex')=>
    53120 if typeof count is 'string'
    5324 if typeof enc is 'number'
    5331 [count,enc] = [enc,count]
    534 else
    5353 enc = count
    5363 count = 32
    53720 bytes = crypto.randomBytes(count)
    53820 if /buffer/i.test enc
    53912 return bytes
    540 else
    5418 return bytes.toString(enc)
    542
    543 # **random_hex** - *generate a string of random hexadecimal characters*

    545 # Generates a string of `count` pseudo-random hexadecimal digits.
    5461 @random_hex:(count=32)=>Util._random_digits(count,16)
    547
    548 # **random_alphanumeric** - *generate a string of random numbers and letters*
    549 #
    550 # Generates a string of `count` pseudo-random characters from the set `[a-z0-9]`.
    5514 @random_alphanumeric:(count=32)=>Util._random_digits(count,36)
    552
    553 # **_random_digits** - *generate a string of random bytes in the specfied base number system*
    554 #
    555 # (An internal method that generates `count` characters in the specfified base.)
    556 @_random_digits:(count=32,base)=>
    5575 str = ""
    5585 while str.length < count
    55918 str += Math.random().toString(base).substring(2)
    5605 if str.length > count
    5614 str = str.substring(0,count)
    5625 return str

    564 # ## Comparators and Sorting
    565
    566 # **slow_equals** - *constant-time comparison of two buffers for equality*
    567 # Performs a byte by byte comparision of the given buffers
    568 # but does it in *constant* time (rather than aborting as soon
    569 # as a delta is discovered). `a^b` (`a xor b`) would be better
    570 # if supported.
    571 #
    572 # To prevent optimizations from short-cutting this process, an array
    573 # containing `[ equal?, number-of-identical-bytes, number-of-different-bytes ]`
    574 # is returned.
    575 #
    576 # For equality tests, you'll want something like `if(Util.slow_equals(a,b)[0])`.
    577 #
    578 @slow_equals:(a,b)=>
    57912010 same_count = delta_count = 0
    58012010 if b.length > a.length
    5811 [a,b] = [b,a]
    58212010 for i in [0...a.length]
    58398330808 if a[i] isnt b[i]
    58446247905 delta_count += 1
    585 else
    58652082903 same_count += 1
    58712010 if (delta_count is 0 and a.length is b.length)
    5886004 return [true,same_count,delta_count]
    589 else
    5906006 return [false,same_count,delta_count]
    591
    592 # Compare the `expected_digest` with the hash computed from the remaining
    593 # parameters.
    594 @validate_hashed_password:(expected_digest,password,salt,pepper,hash_type)=>
    5953 [salt,digest] = @hash_password(password,salt,pepper,hash_type)
    5963 password = undefined # forget password when no longer needed
    5973 return Util.slow_equals(expected_digest,digest)[0]
    598
    599 # Hash the given `password`, optionally using the given `salt`.
    600 # If no `salt` is provided a new random salt will be generated.
    601 # Returns `[salt,digest]`.
    602 # options := { password, salt, pepper, hash_type }
    603 @hash_password:(password,salt,pepper,hash_type)=>
    604 # parse input parameters
    60520 if typeof password is 'object'
    6062 hash_type = password.hash_type
    6072 pepper = password.pepper
    6082 salt = password.salt
    6092 password = password.password
    610 # set defaults
    61120 hash_type ?= 'sha512'
    61220 salt ?= 64
    613 # convert types
    61420 password = new Buffer(password) if password? and not Buffer.isBuffer(password)
    61520 pepper = new Buffer(pepper) if pepper? and not Buffer.isBuffer(pepper)
    61620 if typeof salt is 'number'
    6179 salt = Util.random_bytes(salt,'buffer')
    61811 else unless Buffer.isBuffer(salt)
    6191 salt = new Buffer(salt)
    620 # validate inputs
    62120 if not password?
    6221 throw new Error("password parameter is required")
    623 else
    624 # calculate hash
    62519 hash = crypto.createHash(hash_type)
    62619 hash.update salt
    62719 if pepper?
    6289 hash.update pepper
    62919 hash.update password
    63019 password = undefined # forget password when no longer needed
    63119 digest = hash.digest()
    632 # return generated salt and calculated hash
    63319 return [salt,digest]
    634
    635 # **compare** - *a basic comparator function*
    636 #
    637 # A basic comparator, using JavaScript's default `<` and `>` operators.
    638 # Allows `null` values, which are sorted before any non-null values.
    639 #
    640 # Returns:
    641 # - a positive integer when `a > b`, or when `a` is not `null` and `b` is `null`
    642 # - a negative integer when `a < b`, or when `a` is `null` and `b` is not `null`
    643 # - zero (`0`) otherwise (when `!(a > b) && !(a < b)` or when both `a` and `b` are `null`).
    644 @compare:(a,b)=>
    64594 if a? and b?
    64663 return (if a > b then 1 else (if a < b then -1 else 0))
    64731 else if a? and not b?
    64810 return 1
    64921 else if b? and not a?
    65010 return -1
    651 else
    65211 return 0
    653
    654 # **case_insensitive_compare** - *a case-insensitive comparator function*
    655 #
    656 # Compares to elements (exactly like `compare`), with two exceptions:
    657 # 1. Any string-valued argument is converted to upper case before the comparison.
    658 # 2. If the case-insensitive comparison yields `0` (i.e., the two case-insensitive
    659 # values are equal), a case-sensitive comparison is used as a tie-breaker).
    660 @case_insensitive_compare:(a,b)=>
    66116 if a?.toUpperCase?
    66210 A = a.toUpperCase()
    663 else
    6646 A = a
    66516 if b?.toUpperCase?
    66610 B = b.toUpperCase()
    667 else
    6686 B = b
    66916 result = Util.compare(A,B)
    67016 if result is 0
    6718 result = Util.compare(a,b)
    67216 return result
    673
    674 # **field_comparator** - *compares objects based on an attribute*
    675 #
    676 # Generates a comparator that compares objects based on the specified field.
    677 # E.g., `field_comparator('foo')` will compare two objects `A` and `B`
    678 # based on the value of `A.foo` and `B.foo`.
    679 #
    680 # When `ignore_case` is `true`, string-valued fields will be compared in a
    681 # case-insensitive way.
    68211 @field_comparator:(field,ignore_case=false)=>@path_comparator([field],ignore_case)
    683
    684 # **path_operator** - *compares objects based on (optionally nested) attributes*
    685 #
    686 # Generates a comparator that compares objects based on the value obtained
    687 # by walking the given path (in an object graph).
    688 #
    689 # E.g., `path_comparator(['foo','bar'])` will compare two objects `A` and `B`
    690 # based on the value of `A.foo.bar` and `B.foo.bar`.
    691 #
    692 # If a `null` value is encountered while walking the object-graph, the
    693 # two values are immediately compared. (Hence given:
    694 #
    695 # a = { foo: null }
    696 # b = { foo: { bar: null } }
    697 # path = [ 'foo','bar' ]
    698 #
    699 # `path_comparator(path)(a,b)` will compare `null` and `{ bar: null }`, since
    700 # the value of `a.foo` is `null`.)
    701 #
    702 # When `ignore_case` is `true`, string-valued fields will be compared in a
    703 # case-insensitive way.
    704 #
    705 @path_comparator:(path,ignore_case=false)=>
    70627 (a,b)=>
    70745 fn = if ignore_case then 'case_insensitive_compare' else 'compare'
    70845 A = a
    70945 B = b
    71045 for f in path
    71174 A = A?[f]
    71274 B = B?[f]
    71374 unless A? and B? # should we continue walking the graph if one of the values is not-null?
    71418 return Util[fn](A,B)
    71527 return Util[fn](A,B)
    716
    717 # **desc_comparator** - *reverses another comparison function.*
    718 #
    719 # Generates a comparator that reverses the sort order of the input comparator.
    720 # I.e., if when sorted by comparator `c` an array is ordered `[1,2,3]`, the
    721 # array will be ordered `[3,2,1]` when sorted by `desc_comparator(c)`.
    72212 @desc_comparator:(c)=>((a,b)->(c(b,a)))
    723
    724 # **descending_comparator** - *an alias for `desc_comparator`*
    7256 @descending_comparator:(args...)=>@desc_comparator(args...)
    726
    727 # **composite_comparator** - *chains several comparison functions into one*
    728 #
    729 # Given a list (array) of comparators, generates a comparator that first
    730 # compares elements by list[0], then list[1], etc. until a non-equal
    731 # comparision is found, or we run out of comparators.
    732 @composite_comparator:(list)=>
    7339 (a,b)->
    7349 for c in list
    73521 r = c(a,b)
    73621 unless r is 0
    7376 return r
    7383 return 0

    740 # ## Various Other Utilities
    741
    742 # Identifies the "client IP" for the given request in various circumstances
    743 @remote_ip:(req)=>
    7443 req?.get?('x-forwarded-for') ?
    745 req?.headers?['x-forwarded-for'] ?
    746 req?.connection?.remoteAddress ?
    747 req?.socket?.remoteAddress ?
    748 req?.connection?.socket?.remoteAddress
    749
    750 # **handle_error** - *invoke a callback on error*
    751 #
    752 # If `err` is `null` (or `undefined`), returns
    753 # `false`.
    754 #
    755 # If `err` is not `null`, and `callback` exists,
    756 # invokes `callback(err)` and returns `true`.
    757 #
    758 # If `err` is not `null`, `callback` does not
    759 # exist and `thrown_when_no_callback` is `true`
    760 # (the default), `throws` the given error.
    761 #
    762 # If `err` is not `null`, `callback` does not
    763 # exist and `thrown_when_no_callback` is `false`,
    764 # prints the `err` to STDERR and returns `true`.
    765 #
    766 # Particularly useful for the CoffeeScript idiom:
    767 #
    768 # some_error_generating_function a, b, (err,foo,bar)->
    769 # unless Util.handle_error err, callback
    770 # # ...continue processing...
    771 #
    772 # rather than:
    773 #
    774 # some_error_generating_function a, b, (err,foo,bar)->
    775 # if err?
    776 # callback(err)
    777 # else
    778 # # ...continue processing...
    779 #
    780 @handle_error:(err,callback,throw_when_no_callback=true)=>
    7816 if err?
    7823 if callback?
    7831 callback(err)
    7841 return true
    7852 else if throw_when_no_callback
    7861 throw err
    787 else
    7881 console.error "ERROR",err
    789 else
    7903 return false
    791
    792 # **uuid** - *normalize or generate a UUID value*
    793 #
    794 # When a UUID value `v` is provided, a normalized value is returned (downcased and
    795 # with any dashes (`-`) removed, matching `/^[0-9a-f]{32}$/`).
    796 #
    797 # E.g., given `02823B75-8C4A-3BC4-7F03-0A8482D5A9AB`, returns `02823b758c4a3bc47f030a8482d5a9ab`.
    798 # If `generate` is `true` and `v` is `null`, a new (normalized) UUID value is generated and returned.
    799 @uuid:(v,generate=false)=>
    80030 unless v?
    80112 if generate
    8024 v = Util.uuid(uuid.v1())
    803 else
    8048 return null
    80518 else unless v.replace?
    8061 throw new Error("Expected string but found #{typeof v}",v)
    80717 else unless /^[0-9a-f]{8}-?[0-9a-f]{4}-?[0-9a-f]{4}-?[0-9a-f]{4}-?[0-9a-f]{12}$/i.test v
    8081 throw new Error("Encountered invalid UUID format #{v}.")
    80920 return v.replace(/-/g,'').toLowerCase()
    810
    811 # **pad_uuid** - *normalize or generate a *padded* UUID value*
    812 #
    813 # When a UUID value `v` is provided, a normalized value is returned (matching
    814 # `/^[0-9a-f]{8}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{12}$/`).
    815 #
    816 # If `generate` is `true` and `v` is `null`, a new (normalized) UUID value
    817 # is generated and returned.
    818 @pad_uuid:(v,generate=false)=>
    81910 v = @uuid(v,generate)
    82010 if v?
    8216 return (v.substring(0,8)+"-"+v.substring(8,12)+"-"+v.substring(12,16)+"-"+v.substring(16,20)+"-"+v.substring(20))
    822 else
    8234 return null
    824
    825 # **b64e** - *encodes a buffer as Base64*
    826 #
    827 # Base64-encodes the given Buffer or string, returning a string.
    828 # When a string value is provided, the optional `output_encoding` attribute
    829 # specifies the encoding to use when converting characters to bytes.
    830 @b64e:(buf,output_encoding='utf8')=>
    8315 if not buf?
    8321 return null
    833 else
    8344 unless buf instanceof Buffer
    8354 buf = new Buffer(buf.toString(),output_encoding)
    8364 return buf.toString('base64')
    837
    838 # **b64d** - *decodes a Base64-encoded string*
    839 #
    840 # Base64-decodes the given Buffer or string, returning a string.
    841 # The optional `output_encoding` attribute specifies the encoding to use
    842 # when converting bytes to characters.
    843 @b64d:(buf,output_encoding='utf8')=>
    8445 if not buf?
    8451 return null
    846 else
    8474 unless buf instanceof Buffer
    8484 buf = new Buffer(buf.toString(),'base64')
    8494 return buf.toString(output_encoding)
    850
    851 # **for_async** - *executes an asynchronous `for` loop.*
    852 #
    853 # Accepts 5 function-valued parameters:
    854 # * `initialize` - an initialization function (no arguments passed, no return value is expected)
    855 # * `condition` - a predicate that indicates whether we should continue looping (no arguments passed, a boolean value is expected to be returned)
    856 # * `action` - the action to take (a single callback function is passed and should be invoked at the end of the action, no return value is expected)
    857 # * `increment` - called at the end of every `action`, prior to `condition` (no arguments passed, no return value is expected)
    858 # * `whendone` - called at the end of the loop (when `condition` returns `false`), (no arguments passed, no return value is expected)
    859 #
    860 # For example, the loop:
    861 #
    862 # for(var i=0; i<10; i++) { console.log(i); }
    863 #
    864 # could be implemented as:
    865 #
    866 # var i = 0;
    867 # init = function() { i = 0; }
    868 # cond = function() { return i < 10; }
    869 # actn = function(next) { console.log(i); next(); }
    870 # incr = function() { i = i + 1; }
    871 # done = function() { }
    872 # for_async(init,cond,actn,incr,done)
    873 #
    874 @for_async:(initialize,condition,action,increment,whendone)=>
    8752 looper = ()->
    8769 if condition()
    8778 action ()->
    8787 increment()
    8797 looper()
    880 else
    8811 whendone() if whendone?
    8822 initialize()
    8832 looper()
    884
    885 # **for_each_async** - *executes an asynchronous `forEach` loop.*
    886 #
    887 # Accepts 3 parameters:
    888 # * `list` - the array to iterate over
    889 # * `action` - the function with the signature (value,index,list,next) indicating the action to take; the provided function `next` *must* be called at the end of processing
    890 # * `whendone` - called at the end of the loop
    891 #
    892 # For example, the loop:
    893 #
    894 # [0..10].foreach (elt,index,array)-> console.log elt
    895 #
    896 # could be implemented as:
    897 #
    898 # for_each_async [0..10], (elt,index,array,next)->
    899 # console.log elt
    900 # next()
    901 #
    902 @for_each_async:(list,action,whendone)=>
    9032 i = m = null
    9042 init = ()-> i = 0;
    9052 cond = ()-> (i < list.length)
    9062 incr = ()-> i += 1
    9072 act = (next)-> action(list[i],i,list,next)
    9082 Util.for_async(init, cond, act, incr, whendone)
    909
    910 # **procedure** - *generates a new `Sequencer` object, as described below.*
    9112 @procedure:()=>(new Sequencer())
    912
    913# **Sequencer** - *a simple asynchronous-method-chaining utility*
    914#
    915# The `Sequencer` class provides a simple utility for
    916# chaining together callback-based methods in a more "linear"
    917# style.
    918#
    919# For example, rather than writing (in CoffeeScript):
    920#
    921# method_one ()=>
    922# method_two ()=>
    923# method_three ()=>
    924# and_so_on ()=>
    925#
    926# We can flatten the calls out like this:
    927#
    928# procedure = Util.procedure()
    929# procedure.first( method_one )
    930# procedure.then( method_two )
    931# procedure.then( method_three )
    932# procedure.then( and_so_on )
    933# procedure.run()
    934#
    935# Each call to `then` appends the given callback method
    936# to the chain.
    937#
    938# Each callback method is passed a `next_step` function that *must*
    939# be called to trigger the next step in the processing.
    940#
    941# Hence the typical use of the class looks something like this:
    942#
    943# s = new Sequencer()
    944# s.first (done)->
    945# # do something, then invoke the callback
    946# done()
    947# s.next (done)->
    948# # do something else, then invoke the callback
    949# done()
    950# s.next (done)->
    951# # do one more thing, then invoke the callback
    952# done()
    953# s.run()
    954#
    955# When `run` is invoked, each asynchronous method is executed in sequence.
    956#
    957# The `first` method is optional (you can just use `next` instead), but when
    958# invoked `first` will remove any methods previously added to the chain.
    959#
    960# You `last` methods is an optional short-hand for adding one final method to
    961# the chain and then running it. E.g., the last two lines of our example:
    962#
    963# procedure.then( and_so_on )
    964# procedure.run()
    965#
    966# Could be re-written:
    967#
    968# procedure.last( and_so_on )
    969#
    970# Note that the sequence is not cleared when `run` is invoked, so one may
    971# invoke `run` more than once to execute the sequence again.
    972#
    9731class Sequencer
    9741 constructor:()->
    9752 @list = []
    976
    977 # `first` removes any methods previously added to
    978 # the chain, and then adds the given method to
    979 # the newly empty list.
    980 first:(step)=>
    9812 @list = []
    9822 @list.push step
    9832 return this
    984
    985 # `next` adds a new method to the chain
    986 next:(step)=>
    9876 @list.push step
    9886 return this
    989
    990 # `then` is an alias for `next`
    9913 then:(step)=>@next(step)
    992
    993 # `last` will add the given method to the chain
    994 # and then invoke `run(callback)` to execute the
    995 # entire procedure.
    996 last:(step,callback)=>
    9971 @next(step)
    9981 @run(callback)
    9991 return this
    1000
    1001 # `finally` is an alias for `last`
    10021 finally:(step,callback)=>@last(step,callback)
    1003
    1004 # `run` will execute each function in the chain in sequence.
    1005 # When a `callback` method is provided it will be
    1006 # invoked after all methods in the chain have completed execution.
    1007 run:(args...,callback)=>
    10082 action = (step,index,list,next)=>
    10098 step args..., (new_args...)=>
    10107 args = new_args
    10117 next()
    10122 Util.for_each_async @list,action,()=>callback?(args...)
    10132 return this
    1014
    1015 # Note that each `Sequencer` method returns the `Sequencer` object
    1016 # itself. Hence given (predefined) functions `a`, `b`, and `c`,
    1017 # one could invoke:
    1018 #
    1019 # (new Sequencer()).first(a).then(b).finally(c)
    1020 #
    1021
    1022
    1023# ## Exports
    1024
    1025# The `Util` and `Sequencer` types are exported by this module.
    1026
    10271exports.Util = Util
    10281exports.Sequencer = Sequencer
    1029
